body: I was having a bit of a challenge reviewing as is, so I squashed and pushed up to my fork: https://github.com/trkurc/nifi/commit/099fb1b0e517640d32c4c69deb4fc01882b0cb00

@rickysaltzer Did another review on this and overall things look pretty good and the issues of bigger concern seem to be corrected.  I left an additional patch on the ticket with some stylistic items and version update (0.4.2-SNAPSHOT) changes I would like to apply on top of your patch.  

My final comments are concerning some of the properties.  In the case of the metric property, this is something that you use as a float to provide in the transmission to the Riemann server.  It would be good to include this in the property descriptor to make this a little clearer.  This should also be applied to the TTL and time properties.  I did some digging to try to figure out how to flesh this out more, but wasn't quite sure how to best describe them.  If you can provide some additional detail on those and the anticipated input, it would certainly help.  Apologies if this is a misunderstanding on my behalf, still quite the Riemann novice.

Also, the caught NumberFormatException would likely benefit from a log syntax more along the lines of:

```
        getLogger().warn("Unable to create Riemann event.", e);
```

This coincides with the above comments regarding the enhanced descriptions of the number driven values.

Thanks again for the updates though and with some additional details on the properties I think we are good to go!  Thanks for all your efforts!
Thanks @apiri, I'll try and update a few of the descriptions to make things more clear and upload a new patch. Cheers
Awesome, thanks!

The latest patch should address most of the description concerns. I'm in the process of running all NiFi tests now and doing a final workflow test with a current `master` build. I will report results shortly. Thanks again.

@olegz - I'm very happy that you are digging in here. This bit of code certainly could use some TLC and refactoring. I very much like the approach of moving this logic into the StandardControllerServiceNode object instead of the scheduler. I did notice one issue that appears to be a race condition if enable() and disable() are running in parallel (commented inline). Otherwise, I've not seen any other issues but will continue to review this. Thanks again for tackling this!
Tests pass, and my few workflows I created behave as expected. If it's okay with you @apiri, I'd like to re-base my changes throughout this PR into one commit before I push upstream.

@rickysaltzer Sounds fair.  I had squashed/pushed to my personal fork at a35be5e358108a48b34de3fcf5edcb428a794d03 to make the review a little easier.  Additionally, there were a couple of style items I patched up as well as marking OnScheduled/OnStopped variables as volatile in 1d4fdfe57c9d966c0be6fd5cc537623854f4491c.  If they seem fair, I can merge them to accompany your contribution and push it all together.

Let me know what works and sounds good to you.  Thanks!

Oh nice, I'll see about merging your changes after I squash mine. Would it be okay if I push this patch once it's ready? I haven't yet verified I'm even able to push upstream, and now seems like a good time to try that out.

Yep, of course and please do!  Just was trying to save some unnecessary keystrokes if not needed.  Let me know if you hit any hurdles.  Presumably you can access https://github.com/apiri/incubator-nifi/commit/1d4fdfe57c9d966c0be6fd5cc537623854f4491c.patch to grab a patch for that commit and overlay it on yours.  I am sure there is a more elegant way, however I am also sure I don't know what that is off the top of my head ;)

Regardless, +1 with those changes and the work in your latest push to the PR.
@apiri awesome, your patch applied without issue!
@leelaim1 Thanks for the contribution and taking the time to submit a fix for these items you noticed.  Will review shortly and get these incorporated.

This was merged and incorporated into the codebase.  Fixes to documentation are always great and thanks again for taking the time to go the extra mile and submit a patch for the items you found.  The NiFi community appreciates your efforts!
added more comments on the NIFI-1156 ticket.
Mark Payne commented on NIFI-1333 ticket.  In short the write lock does appear no longer necessary but a readLock still is.
I just pushed changes that address these issues, including tests for these and a couple more edge conditions.  It has been squashed (thanks @trkurc) into a single commit for readability.

I'm closing this pull request since the general S3 changes have been incorporated by @trkurc.  The remaining Multipart Upload functionality will be incorporated into a new pull request in conjunction with S3 bucket and local state cleanup functionality.
@alopresto Would you mind closing this out?  I forgot to add the magic incantation with your patch when committing.  Sorry!
Closing per Aldrin.

Woohoo!  The build even passed on here via the PR.  Had me nervous :relieved: 

As a reminder, the Travis job does a mvn clean install -Pcontrib-check so it should realistically just come down to a code review as long as the build is green.
@thadguidry Good find and thanks for the taking time to provide this adjustment to make our build a little less chatty.  Will get this merged in shortly.  Thanks!
Reviewing...
Code changes look good. Verified compatability existing NiFi installs. Needed to address a few minor contrib-check issues.
@jvwing - nice catch! Will merge this in shortly.
LGTM

@jdye64 I left a lot of inline comments while doing a code review. Mostly just pointing out either naming conventions that we should strive to be consistent with, or pointing out some utils/convenience methods that will help to keep the code clean.

Overall, I think it's an awesome contribution! Thanks for putting in all of the effort to get this going. Code looks great overall - excellent unit tests to verify behavior. Very cool stuff!
Since the length check confused two people I'm changing it to `> -1`.
At first glance, looks good, will do some checks and merge unless I find something.

NIFI-1385

This also fixes the failing test on Windows due to differing error messages on various OS.
Cool. thx @trkurc
@trkurc went ahead with your suggestion. It's definitely safer.
@olegz  - going to test build on a couple of platforms before I merge this in
@markap14 @joewitt Guys, please review. As agreed I've put read lock back in.
thanks oleg.  i won't be able to help today most likely . Hopefully payne-monster or someone else can.
@olegz  - I'll dig my old notes out and try to verify that a read-lock won't continue to cause a deadlock. I will likely have some time later this evening.
Taking Joe's feedback I merged the two processors InferAvroSchemaFromCSV and InferAvroSchemaFromJSON into a single processor InferAvroSchema.
I agree that the file should not be created relative to the HOME directory, but can we use something relative to the local target/ directory instead of an absolute path?

@mattyb149 I think the reason it had an absolute path was due to the below error from the H2 driver:

org.h2.jdbc.JdbcSQLException: A file path that is implicitly relative to the current working directory is not allowed in the database URL "jdbc:h2:file:target/db/testdb7". Use an absolute path, ~/name, ./name, or the baseDir setting instead. [90011-187]
Sorry this PR has lingered this long. It looks like the current release of Spring is 4.2.4.RELEASE. Would you be able to update your branch to reflect this version? Thanks!
At the moment I agree, this should not be merged as it was primarily done to start the conversation - https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=61336327
I think it may still deadlock. I scripted a startup and shutdown over and over again for a few days, and it still was hanging on occasion. I should have added a jstack..

I am not surprised, that's why I was against having a lock in a shutdown in the first place. It doesn't bring any value since If you follow the logic of shutting down executors we are shutting them down cold anyway if they have not shut down in timely fashion.
Reviewing...

The build infrastructure changes look good. I realize the motivation for this ticket was establishing this baseline. However, I wanted to try to run the integration tests to verify they actually ran and everything looked good. The documentation for these integration tests states it requires additional configuration and resources/buckets. Should part of this effort be defining how integration tests relay required setup instructions?

Not opposed but not sure how to best accomplish this. A section in the dev or contrib guide talking about how to activate and or what is currently present seem reasonable? Agree that there should be some documentation to highlight the new profile at minimum. Other suggestions?

Highlighting the existence of the new profile is a good idea and we should do that. However, I was specifically referring to the AWS integration tests that are part of this PR. I wanted to be able to activate the new profile and make sure the integration tests ran and everything looked good. But the integration tests require some additional configuration and resources. However, it does not explain what those are or how to set them up. Do we want to try to document the dependencies a given integration test has so that other developers can run them as well?

Sorry went off on a tangent on the previous part. In favor of that but curious as to what the destination should be. Didn't do the integration test classes myself but can comb through and pull out the relevant pieces, just not sure where the documentation of such should live.

Yep, I realize this PR was just trying to establish the baseline and create the build infrastructure. I can certainly +1 that aspect. I was just wondering if this sort of thing warranted a best practice/convention. If the expectation is that only folks intimately familiar with a particular component will run the integration test than they likely don't need any additional documentation. I'm just trying to figure out what the expectation is.

I'm guessing that the integration tests will likely never be run from NiFi root since it could potentially require a lot external configuration and prep work.

Gotcha. There were some good suggestions on the related thread on the mailing list but there are limited classes that fall into this category at this time. Not necessarily sure that this PR will explicitly close the related issue, but could be a first step in the direction of fulfillment.
+1 Went ahead and merged the proposed changes for the build infrastructure. Specifics for this integration test can be updated as needed.
Build looks good. No more artifacts showing up in user home directory. Thanks!
Thanks for merging this PR. Do we similarly modify all of the other TestJdbc\* to take a TemporaryFolder ?

I wasn't aware of any issues with the other JDBC tests. This JIRA was created to specifically address the tests resources being created in the user's HOME directory. If there are any issues with the other tests we should address those as well with a separate ticket. Thanks again for the contribution!
reviewing now.
I like the docs to help with reviewing! I good amount here to review and test!
Reviewing...
@mcgilman Refactored this a bit to adjust given your commentary and avoided making some of those determinations when we are not sending a flowfile.

Jeremy,

I've been reviewing this and I made a handful of minor changes:
- Copied licensing information to the nar - it was already present in nifi-assembly. Just had to create a LICENSE file for the nar itself.
- Updated version from 0.4.0-SNAPSHOT to 0.4.2-SNAPSHOT
- Improved error handling (if we hit any RuntimeException, such as the Content Repository is out of disk space, it was routing to the "invalid html" relationship)
- Updated some code to match the nifi style a bit more (adding 'final' keywords, using longer max line width (200 chars is the max we use with nifi))

I did not change the logic of any of the Processors, though. All very solid stuff.
Excited to see this getting into NiFi! Thanks for all of the work that you've put into this!
Looks good!
~smarthi - thanks for fixing this up and contributing it back! I've merged it into master.
Thanks!

@olegz  - to sort of summarize, I definitely understand the issue with the uri and only being able to fully verify "at runtime", it also makes sense to deal with obvious mistakes in the validator. In that sense, my expectation was better error handling, not wholesale removal. 

I had thought you were operating along these lines too, by leaving in the URI_VALIDATOR, but removing the unit tests for that were a surprise.

@trkurc I do see your point, so let me throw something else at you. The _URI_VALIDATOR_ simply validates based on success of this `new URI(input);` and we can certainly add the test back, but consider that that test was added by Joe to validate the previous fix that we all seem to agree was inefficient given what we know now. So instead I've added 3 more tests to test specific invalid conditions. 
That leaves us with one thing and that is testing that 'any validator' works in the processor and as I said before I think those tests already exists at the higher level.

Spent some time reviewing the patch. Overall, I think the code looks good. Additional nit-picky item outside of my previous comment.
- I could see possibly wanting to extract the RELP utility classes into a separate artifact. Maybe we wait to shuffle this around until we have a case for it. Maybe introduce a RELP NAR if we ever get to that point.

When running ListenRELP, there were times (especially right after stopping and starting the Processor) that new messages were not picked up for some time. At some point later, a backlog of messages flooded in. It's not clear what triggered it and the backlog appeared to produce some duplicate messages.

@trkurc did you want to check this out before we proceed with merging?
@mcgilman - I have been reviewing. I should be complete tonight. Haven't found any show stoppers yet.

Thanks for reviewing @mcgilman and @trkurc ! 

I pushed up a small commit that fixed a couple of minor logging issues and addressed the comment Matt made about the pool of buffers. 

Will wait to see any feedback from Tony and can address anything else as needed.

Is it my impression or this controller is embedding elastic search into NiFi in order to use the Transport protocol?

Would this cause all sort of issues around versioning? Even logstash moved the default behaviour from using transport clients into the HTTP bulk api.

Elastic.co is quite explicit in stating the benefits on using the HTTP API:

> This output lets you store logs in Elasticsearch using the native node and transport
> protocols. It is highly recommended to use the regular logstash-output-elasticsearch 
> output which uses HTTP instead. This output is, in-fact, sometimes slower, and never
> faster than that one. Additionally, upgrading your Elasticsearch cluster may require 
> you to simultaneously update this plugin for any protocol level changes. The HTTP
> client may be easier to work with due to wider familiarity with HTTP.

Yes this controller is using the Transport protocol. The explicit docs you mention are logstash docs, not elasticsearch docs. The Elasticsearch Java Client docs (https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/client/java-api/current/index.html) make no mention that the HTTP APIs are more performant and recommended.

Having said that, the updating of versions is indeed a concern, so perhaps the NiFi processors should be able to use the HTTP APIs (in addition to or instead of). At present the *-Http processors in NiFi should already enable this type of interaction. I presumed (apparently incorrectly) that a native transport would be faster, or else why have it?

I appreciate your feedback, and will think on these points.

@mattyb149 very good point... very good point

Indeed and according to a blog post on found.no(Elastic's cloud offering) back in January suggested the use of transport client:

https://www.elastic.co/blog/found-interfacing-elasticsearch-picking-client

So you are 100% right. 

Seems like elastic.co has a differing view on what method to use depending the scope of the integration.

However, to make things worse the same blog post also make statements like:

> JVM update version on both the clients and the servers due to exception serializing 
> and other potential minor differences between updates.

Meanwhile community comments on mixed versions compatibility seem to be mixed bag as we [see](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/elasticsearch/nBJ-Rz1kX6Y/flAO0zqjULcJ) [here](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/issues/13273#issuecomment-169189577)

To be completely honest, we face the same issue with Kafka NAR, however, it feels like the Kafka's API policy is explicit about a strong desire to support older clients, while Elastic.co policy seems to be version parity. 

Keen to hear what the rest of the folks say.

_Regarding using the *Http processors:_

Can the PostHTTP processor craft a JSON payload as required by the HTTP Bulk API or would it require people to use other processors to do it?

My impression was that the pure PostHTTP cannot be used to achieve ES connectivity easily but I may be wrong.

This is by the way the beauty of the PutElasticSearch you put together: it seems so simple to use! Flowfile in, elasticsearch out. **Extreme awesomeness**.

From a user standpoint I guess this is what people expect to achieve when they request the ability to push and fetch data into/from ES. The functionality helps to reduce their learning curve, reduces duplication (and offloads the works to the development team...).

You are right that more processing would be needed to coax the flow file into the right format for the *Http processors. If the ES processors were to use the HTTP API then it would take care of that for you.

Perhaps the prudent way forward is to get these processors out into the world (using the Transport client since it's done) and see what the community thinks. We will eventually have a registry where new versions (and perhaps one that uses the HTTP API) could be added and the user could select which one(s) they want.  What are your thoughts on this?
@bbende - this is an awesome contribution. most of my comments are minor and of the ilk of we should fix next chance we get, with the exception of the 'comand' typo
sounds like a great idea
Not sure that I agree, but I do agree this is a step in the right direction, so I'll merge it in.
PostHTTP has been working like a charm.  However, GetElasticsearch would be a great addition to the "Get" processors.  Preferably, scrolling.

@bbende I have been running some tests that I usually use around reliable destinations (disconnects, repeated messages, unexpected restarts) and all worked to expected (except for the issue already noted by @mcgilman). 

Amazing code and it certainly enable NiFi to have a greater number of inbound protocols. I will port my Lumberjack spaghetti into the new and cleaner code.
@trkurc I understand and thank you for merging it. That said, there are improvements efforts under way which hopefully would address all of our concerns.

@trkurc @joewitt @markap14  Ok, I was not able to reproduce the deadlock with _readLock_, that said I am voting for removal of any lock from stop routine to avoid further confusion and potential to a misleading message to be interpreted by a user, especially since we will still bring NiFi to a halt - no matter what.
@jdye64 - this is awesome! A few NiFi-isms to work out, which i commented on inline but otherwise looks good to go. Thanks for all of the work that you've put in here!

Just a quick update on the scenario where some messages get resent... 

I turned on rsyslog debug and I noticed that rsyslog seemed to be queueing up responses until 128 responses were received at which point it processed all the responses and started back over, this was consistent with a long running test. So if you stop and start the processor before that, say when it has received 50 responses, it hasn't processed those yet so it thinks those 50 messages need to be resent.

There may be some advanced config in rsyslog to control this, but I am convinced we are sending the correct responses and believe we are good to merge this.
Awesome @bbende great work! I'll go ahead and merge this in now. Thanks everyone!

@olegz - I am still working through the locking on paper. I gave up on getting stack traces. We have a week or so before 0.5.0, if I don't make progress I think we go with deadlock. I am beginning to think you're right about it not being necessary.
That 'deadlock' above should be readlock

Hello - can you create a JIRA for this contrib and we can track/discuss there.

Thanks!
Any plan to pull this PR?

Hello

The community is working toward closing down on the 050 release so PR review bandwidth is limited right now.  This PR represents a pretty significant step towards integration with another framework so we need to be thoughtful about the user experience.  So while this represents a very interesting and compelling integration it may take a bit of time to get right.

Now the PR as-is there are a few quick items I've noticed.
-  It still appears the license and notice information included is copy/paste from the Flume nar as originally identified.  Those are very important to to get right.  
-  There does not appear to be any tests.  
-  Documentation on the approach, idea, and processor is very limited.  There is a sentence about it on the JIRA but it would be really helpful to understand more about the idea and how it compliments NiFi and Camel.  Users and developers will definitely want to know this.
- There is a declaration of ThreadLocal usage and then the use of it appears commented out.  This will need to be removed.
- There is use of e.printStackStrack() and this needs to be using the provided processor Logger.
- A camel application context is provided in src/resources but it appears it should be a test resource

Very much appreciate the contribution and effort.  Just need your understanding that things this important take time and a lot of diligence.

Thanks
Joe
it happened often here in the Travis CI environment.  So let's wait 20 mins or so and we'll see.  It never happened for me locally either.
@joewitt Done!  https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-1437

The Travis environment teases out a lot of these troublesome timing cases with its high load.  It is also one that is fraught with issues given the crazy demand.  Hopefully this resolves it, but in general, I mostly ensure that at least a majority of the jobs build to say things are okay.
thank you.  We're digging in hard for the 050 release now so response time on this might be a bit slow.  Thanks for contributing!

So I originally thought about removing the loop in close() which would avoid the locking as you suggested, but I wasn't 100% sure if selector.close() also closed the channels. The JavaDoc says: ``` *

Any uncancelled keys still associated with this selector are * invalidated, their channels are deregistered, and any other resources * associated with this selector are released. ``` As long as "any other resources associated with this selector are released" means "all the channels are closed" then we are good.
Yes, the releasing of resources implies closing. You can easily test it and see broken connection on the client side.

I know these are not definitive sources, but....
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24543675/does-selector-close-closes-all-client-sockets
http://tutorials.jenkov.com/java-nio/selectors.html#close

Pushed up a new commit that combines stop() and close() into a single call for simplicity, basically preventing someone from calling close() without calling stop(). 

Added additional  checks on the stopped flag in the run method:
- Right after returning from select which should happen during close() when selector.wakeup() is called and stopped is already true
- While looping over the selected keys in run() so that we don't modify the keys after being stopped
@jdye64 - it looks like this PR removes the entire nifi-nar-bundles/nifi-ldap-iaa-providers-bundle module. I'm guessing that was an accident :) Can you un-delete that please?
@rpmiskin all looks good - thanks for contributing this back! I have merged to master, so it will be included in the 0.5.0 release. Thanks!
